sentence.text: Female, first examined in the outpatient clinic at 7 years old due to short stature with brachydactyly.
At that age, she complained that she could not ride a bike because her hands were so small that she could not use the bike brake to stop it.
She is the only daughter of non-consanguineous parents.
Pregnancy was uneventful until the 28th week, when oligohydramnios and IUGR were detected.
She was born by C-section at 37 weeks with a birth weight = 1,630 g (−4 SD); birth length = 41 cm (−4.2 SD); and head circumference (OFC) = 32 cm (−1 SD).
Her physical examination showed mild disproportionate short stature with a height of 114.5 cm (−3 SD) due to very small hands (total hand length 10.5 cm and middle finger length 4.2 cm, both −2 SD).

There was a round face with hypoplasia of the middle of the face, a short bulbous nose, and a slightly prominent chin, as well as small feet with a wide hallux and shortening of the digits, especially from the third to the fifth toes (Figure 3).
Serum calcium phosphorus and alkaline phosphatase were normal, however, PTH level was elevated (99.0 pg/ml [reference value = 15–65 pg/ml]).
Endocrinological evaluation diagnosed pseudohypoparathyroidism and hypothyroidism.
At 11 years old, she had avascular necrosis of the right femur head.
Menarche occurred at the age of 13 years.
In her last evaluation, at 14 years old, she seemed a smart girl and was obese (body mass index [BMI] = 31.7).
Her measurement showed weight = 65.750 kg (+2 SD), height = 144 cm (−2.4 SD), OFC = 56.8 cm (+2 SD).

Radiological examination showed advanced carpal maturation and accentuated brachydactyly in hands and feet with involvement of all the long bones, but mainly of the metacarpal and metatarsal bones with cone-shaped epiphyses in hands.
Hypoplasia of the iliac wings, and slight enlargement of the distal metaphysis of the femur, reminiscent of Erlenmeyer shape, were also observed.
Epiphyseal involvement was also observed in femoral heads and the medial portion of the tibial epiphysis; in both regions, some hypoplasia was observed (Figure 3).
Although she had initially been diagnosed as having Acrodysostosis, her endocrinological disturbance led us also to consider Albright dysplasia as a real diagnostic possibility.
The targeted NGS showed a heterozygous pathogenic variant in exon 11 of PRKAR1A gene—c.1102C > T (p.Arg368*), confirming the initial diagnosis of acrodysostosis.
